comment.author: 90851177@N00
comment._content: Can't imagine being a photographer on that beach! The equipment was big and heavy and there was not a lot of help with getting the shot right. Youhad to know what you were doing. Some of these images are just amazing. -- Discovered using FlickrFox. (?²ˣ)

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: There is only one officer with the name Bridges in the official records — that of Major General Sir William Throsby Bridges. He died on 18 May, 1915, 24 days after this photograph was taken, of wounds received at sea. General Bridges was the only soldier whose body was brought back to Australia for burial. "Major General Sir William Throsby BRIDGES (K.C.B. C.M.G. Queen's South Africa Medal. Mentioned in despatches (Gallipoli)), 1st Aust Div., AIF. Born Greenock, Scotland. Married; Soldier, of 21 Tintern Avenue, Toorak, Melbourne, Victoria. Next of kin: Wife; Lady Edith Bridges (nèe Dawson), of same address. Died of wounds at Sea: aboard HMHS 'Gascon', on 18 May 1915, aged 55. Grave: Duntroon, Canberra ACT. [General Bridges was the only soldier whose body was brought back to Australia for burial]" — Anzacs org
